message_1:
What is the enthalpy change of the oxidation of methane to carbon dioxide and water vapor, given that the balanced chemical equation is:

CH4(g) + 2O2(g) → CO2(g) + 2H2O(g)

and the enthalpies of formation of CH4(g), CO2(g), and H2O(g) are -74.87 kJ/mol, -393.51 kJ/mol, and -241.83 kJ/mol, respectively.
message_2:
To calculate the enthalpy change of the reaction, we can use the following formula:

ΔH_reaction = Σ ΔH_f(products) - Σ ΔH_f(reactants)

where ΔH_f is the enthalpy of formation of the compounds.

For the given reaction:

ΔH_reaction = [1 × (-393.51 kJ/mol) + 2 × (-241.83 kJ/mol)] - [1 × (-74.87 kJ/mol) + 2 × 0 kJ/mol]

Note that the enthalpy of formation of O2(g) is 0 kJ/mol since it is in its standard state.

ΔH_reaction = (-393.51 - 2 × 241.83 + 74.87) kJ/mol
ΔH_reaction = (-393.51 - 483.66 + 74.87) kJ/mol
ΔH_reaction = (-801.30 + 74.87) kJ/mol
ΔH_reaction = -726.43 kJ/mol

The enthalpy change of the oxidation of methane to carbon dioxide and water vapor is -726.43 kJ/mol.
